authorsByline: By MATT SEDENSKY, AP National Writer
title: For many with HIV, drugs lifted their death sentence. Now they must face old age.
description: They survived HIV. Now they face old age. Across Africa, a generation for whom HIV was once a death sentence is now growing old, thanks to lifesaving antiretroviral drugs. But survival has come with a...
content:
NKULAGIRIRE, Uganda (AP) — Past a smoldering pile of trash and two bleating goats, through a doorway beginning to buckle beneath the weight of the bricks above, is a darkened room where a skeletal, 70-year-old man lies on a pillowless bed above a floor littered with trash.

The lone window’s shutters are closed but enough shards of sun make it through holes in the corroded roof to see Joseph Malagho’s ribs poke at the skin of his torso and legs like twigs inside his olive green pants. As he struggles to sit up, leaves crinkle beneath him on a soiled sheet. His mattress sags. The air is thick and stale.

Malagho has no illusions about the difficulty of growing old. But the fact that he is here at all is its own miracle.

Across Africa, millions who once faced the death sentence of an HIV infection have survived only to face something nearly as daunting: old age.

As infections have dropped markedly and antiretroviral drugs have reduced mortality, the turnaround of the AIDS crisis has helped build Africa’s longevity revolution. Lives that were expected to be cut short instead continued decades more, changing the demographics of those facing the disease and fueling the rush of people encountering health systems that were never built for old age.

Malagho isn’t sure when he was infected, but he was diagnosed about five years ago. His health has steadily declined since. He has tuberculosis now, too, and can barely stand.

There is barely any soap for his wife to wash him with a rag. His lone source of entertainment, a small radio, has gone dead, and there’s no money for batteries. He has lost most of his teeth and can’t afford dentures, but there is little food to eat anyway.

He urinates into a small white bucket and his wife hurls it outside just as the first drops of rain begin to strafe the roof and start leaking to the space below.

The organization distributes food and medicine to many of its beneficiaries and helps repair homes, install water tanks and provide basic items, like a bed for seniors who are sleeping on dirt floors. But there are limits to what it can do and Nabanoba feels helpless as she stands before Malagho.

She promises him batteries for his radio and exits the home. Sometimes, after visiting him, colleagues will ask her why she’s quiet and she’ll slink off to cry.
summary: For many who once faced the death sentence of an HIV infection, now they must face old age. As infections have decreased and antiretroviral drugs have reduced mortality, the turnaround of the AIDS crisis has led to Africa's longevity revolution. Joseph Malagho, a 70-year-old man who was diagnosed with HIV about five years ago, has been unable to maintain his health and can barely stand. His only entertainment is a small radio, and he has lost most of his teeth and can't afford dentures. The organization that provides food and medicine for many of its beneficiaries, Enlightenment, helps repair homes, install water tanks and provide basic items like a bed for seniors.
shortSummary: The AIDS crisis has transformed Africa, allowing millions to survive, yet leaving behind challenges like poverty, illness, and inadequate health systems.

argos_summary: In Uganda, a 70‑year‑old HIV survivor, Joseph Malagho, illustrates the new challenge of aging among people living with HIV, a demographic shift driven by effective antiretroviral therapy. While the drugs have turned a once‑death sentence into a chronic condition, many, like Malagho, now confront severe health decline, tuberculosis, and inadequate support for basic needs such as food, medicine, and housing. Local NGOs provide limited assistance—food, medicine, and home repairs—but the health system remains ill‑prepared for the growing elderly HIV population. The story highlights the broader demographic and systemic strain as Africa’s HIV survivors age.
